reviewText:
Race‚Äô07 is simply a must to any real sim racer‚Äôs library. It is quite simply the best touring car experience out there. I've put hundreds of hours into this sim, most of which doing competitive league and championship racing at Race2Play.com. The features and details this sim has to offer, especially at the time of its release, were second to none. Comprehensive tire model, very rich setup with (most) cars responding very well to the setup changes, best FWD touring car or similar experience to date, windscreen and visor bug splats/mud with helmets having tear-offs, lots of good add-ons (particularly Retro Expansion!) which gave a variety of cars and more tracks such as the entire Green Hell and a barrage of GT1 - GT3 content with the GTREvo expansion.

The GT car physics are sub-par, I'll be honest. GTR2 was much better for these and GTRE fails to exploit the same GT experience. The formula cars are kind of a hit and miss. You really need to dive into the setup to get these feeling correctly, but the FMaster and FRR are really fun when you do. Unfortunately the Formula cars in this game use GT car brakes! Grand Prix length events with the FRR, even with full brake duct and lower pressure, will overheat and destroy the brakes. Because they overheat at 600C like the GT brakes, instead of overheating at the F1 range of 1000C, which they can easily reach with higher ambient temperature and heavy brake-load circuits. Unfortunately having my brakes fail in two Grands Prix cost me a very prestigious drivers championship at R2P so I remain bitter about that flaw.

But all-in-all the setup depth and complexity and telemetry coming off the car, the amount of cars and the detail put into the individual physics for each (even model-by-model in classes!) is amazing, the detail of the tracks including the bumps and undulations of the surface make driving a F1 or GT1 car on the edge in league racing incredibly intense, and just.. yeah. It's a sim, not an arcade game. If you take the time to learn how to setup each car, push yourself to be consistent and drive it like a sim - drive it like you would a real car - setup your FFB to really feel the front suspension weight transfers this is a driving sim experience like no other!

NOTE: This review includes notes on expansions aswell.
With 800+ Hours played, I think it's safe to say that this game and it's expansions is one that will last the test of time.
It may not have the following of other racing simulators like rFactor or iRacing, but this is easily up there with some/all of the best.
It has a great racing community if you find a relaxed group of racers (RaceDepartment are great for clean racing and no lock-in racing series). The choice of cars across all the expansions is perfect for online racing.
There really is something for everyone, from slow and nimble Mini Coopers, to high powered open wheel racers, to classic and modern muscle cars (Race On expansion).
My favorite part of this game though is it's single player section though. It's ability to play and create championships makes this a great single player game, along with the fact that the AI is actually rather smart to race against compared to other games.

Modding is also fairly popular with this game as is evident by sites like NoGripRacing and RaceDepartment, with various add-on cars and tracks all waiting to be played.

Since this is a racing simulation, it is definitely a greater experience to use a wheel. I highly recommend getting yourself a wheel if you don't have one yet as it will change your experience entirely.
If you don't play racing games that often it's more than acceptable to use a gamepad, it's still good fun but not as good as with a wheel. The game is drivable with a keyboard as well, but that's a last resort.

In short, it's definitely worth getting the whole package: Race Injection, GTR Evo and Race On. It's perfect to me...
For games as a whole, it's easily 8/10.
For racing sims, it's 9/10.

reviewText:
The 'Race' series comes from a little Swedish company called Simbin, not the most evocotive name. But when you take the entire series as a whole, they have created an absolute master piece of PC gaming.

Race 07, the core game of the series, is primarily focused on the WTCC (World Touring Car Championsip) for 2007, along with serveral 'support' series you can race also. Having learnt leassons from previous racing sims, Simbin have just kept adding to the game, & despite the final collection numbering near double figures, the game is still stable, reliable & entertaining as day one.

The one thing that should grab the attention of serious racing-sim fans is the fact that behind the less glamourous series' is in fact nothing less than a licensed version of the rFactor engine, a sim that has gone beyond being a game, it is tool that is even used by top racing teams to train professional drivers!

Once you have the full works of the Race series, you can race everything from Caterhams, MINI Coopers, WTCC cars of various series, Formula BMW, GT cars, muscle cars... The number of different cars on offer is quite astounding.

However, the real bonus to the Race series is that Simbin have left the game entirely open to being heavily modded, & in fact, have made allowances for making the game easy to mod, from car skins, to tracks, graphics tweaks to entirely new cars that have never existed in the game. Despite having added a huge number of mods of various types to my install, the game remains stable & utterly reliable, something that could quite easily be the make or break of a modding favourite.

On the downside, you pretty much need the whole hog to ensure mods will work, meaning you do have to commit to it. Also, given the quality of the 'sim' part, if you don't have, or never intend to, get a steering wheel, don't bother with it, you'll just be wasting the game & not getting the full experience.

It adds up to a game where you can race almost anything you want to, on pretty much any track you like. There are even online racing clubs who use the game.

I've reached a point where I actually wouldn't even consider buying new racing sims as Race has everything I need, with all the quality & realism of a truly great game that could only be this great on a PC.

Don't be deceived by the age or the price of this game. It's very good.

The amount and variety of content puts many later titles to shame, and so does the AI.

For the first time in a long time, I can race the AI without simply strolling through the pack or watching a single file of cars disappear over the horizon leaving me to hot lap alone. In addition, I have yet to be rear ended or shoved off the track by the AI, no matter where I am on track or how slow I am going. If you have track position, the AI will respect that as best it can, however if you try things like cheap late dives up the inside, they will hold their line and you will get clumped. This enables you to battle with the AI for fun under proper 'Queensbury Rules', which is how it should be.

The only other game I can think of at the moment that has AI close to this is Stock Car Extreme.

In addition, the AI cars also have their own little battles between themselves from time to time which helps greatly with the immersion and I have yet to see any AI cars get bunched up and stuck anywhere. (Quick Tip: Don't max out the number of AI cars when you race. Keep the AI numbers on the low side and this will further help to avoid congestion.)

Graphics are fine, and with a little graphics card tweaking (anti-aliasing in particular) it can be made to look very nice - not photo realistic, no - but still nice looking. Smooth and and clean.

Force feedback is also good if you take the time to tweak the settings to your liking. One advantage of being an older game is that there's plenty of information on the internet to help set up most wheels properly.

Kudos also for the clean and clear user interface. Everything is laid out logically, and setting up races and competitions (you can also create your own custom competitions by the way) follows a nice logical flow through track and car selection to get you to race day.

So, if you're at all frustrated whilst waiting for a fix or patch on your latest photo-realistic uber-racing sim, do yourself a favour - spend ¬£2.50 on this and have some serious fun in the mean time.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I have played several Simbin games. All of them including this one are very realistic with excellent steering wheel and force feedback handling.

Some well known sims try to increase the difficulty level by exaggerating greatly all damage the vehicle gets, like in overrevving for a second, there is no such nonsense in this game, it's all pretty realistic.

The graphics in this game are dated but the playability is high. The AI of other drivers could be better, they are overly and unrealistically agressive. The sound is fitting but not memorable.

Highly recommended and good value.

Tip for beginners:
Many people recommend beginners to use driving aids in sim games.
I do not.
If you are, say in your forties and an experienced driver in real life, go for the most realistic, just choose cars in the beginning that are similar to cars you have driven for real.

reviewText:
When you start (I have no idea if you unlock more), there are four cars to choose from. The BMW  handles like a brick, the other two I tried spin out at the slightest twitch from sitting still (even with all the assisted crap on), and the fourth I didn't try because I didn't want to sit through another loading screen to be met with the same results.

Deciding that I should probably work my way through a championship in order to unlock more content, I headed over to the screen and found that the championships available were ones you create yourself.

I must admit that there are a nice selection of tracks, and that I did eventually manage to have some fun when I got into racing. I still, however, don't quite understand how that part works. I set it to five laps but ended up doing limitless amounts to a time limit of what I think was 20 minutes. The aim seemed to be to set the fastest lap time in the alloted time limit, but it also kept reminding me how far behind me the driver in second place was, making me uncertain of the actual goal. And although it seemed under the dialometer that I should visit pit stops at strategic intervals, when I did so I couldn't find any real way to repair my car (although I may not have looked long enough) and when setting off again, the first lap from the pits didn't seem to count towards a time. And also the guy in second place closed our gap by a lap. That was a little terrifying.

Anyway, if you got this game for free, give it a shot because you might get some fun out of it. Despite what it says it actually does have 360 controller support. Other than that, don't spend money on this game. You'll regret it.

In the meantime, I may come back to this and see if I can make better sense out of it. Maybe that's the key to enjoying this game.

First things first: This game is perfectly playable - and vastly enjoyable - with a gamepad. There. I said it.

I'm not saying that it is the BEST way to get the MOST out of the game but the reviews I'm seeing posted that state the game is only playable with a steering wheel are misleading at best.

The only thing that will ruin this great game is a lack of patience. And it does require patience! If I flick the thumbstick too much the car spins; if I squeeze the trigger too much while trying to turn the car spins; one wheel off the track and on the grass? Guess what? The car spins!

However, after a couple of hours focussing on one car (Mini Cooper) on one track (Brands Hatch) I eventually became accustomed to the physics of the game and began to put in some pretty decent lap times. Then, emboldened, I even started removing some of the driving assists. After more hours I became very comfortable and was putting in consistently quick laps.

Now I've just got to learn how to handle the rest of the cars. And how to race round the rest of the tracks. And I can't wait.

If you have patience and either a gaming wheel or a gamepad, buy this game - it's all of ¬£2.49! It is so much more rewarding than any other racing game I have played. Also, there is a modding community that is still very active and has done a great job professionally recreating pretty much every circuit ever raced on. So if you fancy taking a Touring Car or a Formula 3000 car for a spin (literally in my case!) around Snetterton, Aintree, Sepang or even the Top Gear test track then this is the game for you.

First things first: This game is perfectly playable - and vastly enjoyable - with a gamepad. There. I said it.

I'm not saying that it is the BEST way to get the MOST out of the game but the reviews I'm seeing posted that state the game is only playable with a steering wheel are misleading at best.

The only thing that will ruin this great game is a lack of patience. And it does require patience! If I flick the thumbstick too much the car spins; if I squeeze the trigger too much while trying to turn the car spins; one wheel off the track and on the grass? Guess what? The car spins!

However, after a couple of hours focussing on one car (Mini Cooper) on one track (Brands Hatch) I eventually became accustomed to the physics of the game and began to put in some pretty decent lap times. Then, emboldened, I even started removing some of the driving assists. After more hours I became very comfortable and was putting in consistently quick laps.

Now I've just got to learn how to handle the rest of the cars. And how to race round the rest of the tracks. And I can't wait.

If you have patience and either a gaming wheel or a gamepad, buy this game - it's all of ¬£2.49! It is so much more rewarding than any other racing game I have played. I read the reviews and purchased RACE 07 low on funds and looking for something different from my other games. Glad I did! This game is now one of my favorites.

Not having a wheel and only using a mouse and keyboard, I was a bit concerned if it would be all that playable. Rest assure it's not only playable, but downright fun! If you use the keyboard and mouse, by editing the settings and keeping most of the auto settings on, you can for the most part play with just a mouse alone,
You probably couldn't keep up with the big boys and gals online though, also after a couple hours of straight racing my hand tends to cramp up due to tightnig my grip to steer.

The replay viewer and camera controls are another plus. You can go back and watch where you messed up or find out what exactly caused that multi-car pile up.

Yes, the graphics are a bit dated, but when your doing 110+ mph and coming up on a hairpin curve, with bumper to bumper cars, you really should be paying more attention to your driving and not enjoying the scenery, This ain't a Sunday drive game!
Still, the graphics are better than expected and my laptop running Windows 10 an intel core i3-4030U CPU, 6GB RAM, with built in Intel 4400 HD Graphics has no problem running this game smoothly with everything set to max.
Your mileage may vary depending on make and model, so I can't say how good your performance will be.

Haven't tried the multiplayer due to a poor internet connection, so being able to play offline is just about a must and RACE 07 allows you to do just that.

More free mods, car skins and tracks can be found online by doing a search, but read the descriptions and install instructions carefully, with so much DLC addon content available for 07, some downloads require you to have more than just the base game.

I see a wheel and more of the DLC content being added in the near future, best purchse value for the fun in a long time!

RACE 07 is a brilliant package and offers a wide range of motorsports, all of which will be covered in this review. It has a wide variety of circuits and a very good championship career mode. There are many racing disciplines including: World Touring Car Championship (Official, Extreme & Classic), GT (Pro, Sport   & Club), Swedish Touring Car Championship, Road Cars, Camaro Cup, Radical, Caterham, Formula (F3000, Formula Ford, Formula Masters & Formula 1), and Retro (Max & Cool).

The handling is ultra realistic and has realistic tyre and fuel depletion, which can be increased. There can be up to 36 cars on track at one time. There is a number of championships and has the ability to make your own chamionships up! The menus are much better and are far easier to navigate than GTR 2's.

Overall Rating: 9/10

Simbin made some of the best PC road racing games ever in my opinion. It is not the easiest game to learn, but it is very satisfying when you run a good race.

Races can be set to either time or laps. Select the class you would like to races, and even download mods or DLC to add even more classes of cars and tracks. Now this game does not have as many mods available as GTR2, but there is still plenty out there to add to your Race 07 experience as well as three DLC packs and a free add track on which is included with this purchase. I race with a mircosoft 360 wireless controler on my PC, and it is still a blast. Have a wheel and it gets even better.

You can adjust the AI skill to suit your ability, and have an enjoyable race, and don't forget that there are open wheel cars in this game which GTR2 does not include without a mod.

The price is very reasonable, and most computer can run this pretty well.

If you like racing games, do not be afraid to give this game a try. You will be doing yourself a diservice.

I read the reviews and purchased RACE 07 low on funds and looking for something different from my other games. Glad I did! This game is now one of my favorites.

Not having a wheel and only using a mouse and keyboard, I was a bit concerned if it would be all that playable. Rest assure it's not only playable, but downright fun! If you use the keyboard and mouse, by editing the settings and keeping most of the auto settings on, you can for the most part play with just a mouse alone,
You probably couldn't keep up with the big boys and gals online though, also after a couple hours of straight racing my hand tends to cramp up due to tightnig my grip to steer.

The replay viewer and camera controls are another plus. You can go back and watch where you messed up or find out what exactly caused that multi-car pile up.

Yes, the graphics are a bit dated, but when your doing 110+ mph and coming up on a hairpin curve, with bumper to bumper cars, you really should be paying more attention to your driving and not enjoying the scenery, This ain't a Sunday drive game!
Still, the graphics are better than expected and my laptop running Windows 10 an intel core i3-4030U CPU, 6GB RAM, with built in Intel 4400 HD Graphics has no problem running this game smoothly with everything set to max.
Your mileage may vary depending on make and model, so I can't say how good your performance will be.

Haven't tried the multiplayer due to a poor internet connection, so being able to play offline is just about a must and RACE 07 allows you to do just that.

More free mods, car skins and tracks can be found online by doing a search, but read the descriptions and install instructions carefully, with so much DLC addon content available for 07, some downloads require you to have more than just the base game.

I see a wheel and more of the DLC content being added in the near future, best purchse value for the fun in a long time!
